snippet: The pontiff’s roots in Argentina and his championing of the poor are considered vital to stemming the decline of the church’s vast base in the region.
abstract: Pope Francis's trip to South America will pose test of whether his papacy will increase number of Roman Catholic parishioners on the continent and whether he can retain them; Francis's selection was in part acknowledgement of how important Latin America, which contains 40 percent of world's Catholics, is to church's future; Francis's focus on poor also helps increase his appeal in developing world, which is also important for church.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Simon Romero from Rio de Janeiro, Maggy Ayala from Quito, John Gilbert from Buenos Aires, and Gaia Pianigiani from Rome.

lead_paragraph: The pontiff’s roots in Argentina and his championing of the poor are considered vital to stemming the decline of the church’s vast base in the region.

headline.main: Pope Francis’ Visit to Latin America Will Test His Ability to Keep Catholics in the Fold
headline.print_headline: Tour of a Dwindling Stronghold Will Test a Daring Pope’s Appeal
